name: Adhesive strips
advice: Put adhesive strips in your rubbish bin.

name: Australia Post satchels (plastic)
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
You can take it to a REDcycle soft plastics drop-off point at participating supermarkets.
tips: it should be empty and dry.
remove any paper inserts.

name: Balloons
advice: Put balloons in your rubbish bin.

name: Bread bags
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
You can take it to a REDcycle soft plastics drop-off point at participating supermarkets.
tips: empty any remaining bread. Find out ways to use up food scraps.
remove the bread tag. Find out how to dispose of bread tags.

name: Bubble wrap
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
You can take it to a REDcycle soft plastics drop-off point at participating supermarkets.
tips: cut them into A3 size to make sure they fit. Large pieces of bubble wrap are too bulky to be placed in soft plastic bins at supermarkets.
ensure the bubble wrap is dry.

name: Cellophane
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
You can take it to a REDcycle soft plastics drop-off point at participating supermarkets.

name: Cereal box inserts
advice:
But you can still recycle it…

name: Chip packets
advice:
But you can still recycle it…

tips: empty any remaining chips.
ensure chip packets are dry.

name: Cling wrap
advice:
But you can still recycle it...
Only Glad brand and Coles and Woolworths Essentials homebrand cling wrap is accepted at REDcycle soft plastics drop-off points at participating supermarkets.
tips: use reusable glass and plastic containers.
cover food with a plate.
use reusable beeswax, soy or silicon wraps.
cover with foil which can be recycled. Find out how to dispose of aluminium foil.

name: Disposable nappies
advice: Put disposable nappies in your rubbish bin.Update: If you or someone in your household has coronavirus (COVID-19), put the item in a sealed plastic or paper bag and place in your rubbish bin. If other recyclable items have mixed with affected item, they should also be placed in the rubbish bin.

name: Food pouches
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
You can take it to a REDcycle soft plastics drop-off point at participating supermarkets.
tips: empty any remaining food.
put the lid on again.
you do not need to remove the hard plastic tube.

name: Frozen food bags
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
You can take it to a REDcycle soft plastics drop-off point at participating supermarkets.
tips: remove any remaining food.
ensure frozen food bags are dry.

name: Lolly wrappers
advice:
But you can still recycle it…

tips: remove any remaining lollies or chocolate.
ensure lolly wrappers are dry.

name: Plastic bags

cut them into A3 size to make sure they fit. Large pieces of soft plastic are too bulky to be placed in soft plastic bins at supermarkets

name: Reusable shopping bags
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
You can take it to a REDcycle soft plastics drop-off point at participating supermarkets.
tips: make sure it is empty.
leave the plastic base inside as it is fully recyclable too.

name: Biscuit trays
advice:
Unless...
Some councils only accept hard plastics which are coded with a 1 or 2 in the recycling symbol. Check with your local council.
tips: collected by your local council’s kerbside recycling truck.
taken to a recycling sorting facility.
separated from other recyclables, such as steel and cardboard.
taken to a re-processing centre and broken down.
taken to a manufacturer to be made into new products.

advice: But you can still recycle it…Aussie Bread Tags for Wheelchairs is a community program where individuals and organisations collect bread tags to be sold to plastics recycling companies.Find out more about Aussie Bread Tags for Wheelchairs.

name: Meat trays (foam)
advice: Put these in your rubbish bin.

name: Polystyrene
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
See if there are any local polystyrene recycling programs by contacting your local council. If there are none, it goes in your rubbish bin.

name: Bedding
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
You can take bedding to your nearest second-hand store, charity bin or drop-off location.
tips: clean and not stained.
not torn or frayed.

name: Cleaning cloths
advice:
Cleaning clothes go in your rubbish bin.
Update: If you or someone in your household has coronavirus (COVID-19), make sure the used cleaning cloths are inside a plastic or paper bag that is securely closed before being placed in your kerbside rubbish bin. If other recyclable items such as paper and cardboard have mixed with the cleaning cloths, they should also be placed in the rubbish bin.

name: Clothing
advice:
But you can still recycle them…
You can take resaleable clothing to your nearest second-hand store, charity bin or drop-off location.For worn, damaged, and unsaleable clothing, retailers H&M, Zara and Manrags each have garment collection programs for clothing or textiles.
tips: clean and not stained.
not covered in animal fur.
not torn or frayed.

name: Curtains
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
You can take curtains to your nearest second-hand store, charity bin or drop-off location.
tips: clean and not faded.
not covered in animal fur.

name: Masks (cloth)
advice:
Cloth face masks that are worn out go in your rubbish bin.
Update: If you or someone in your household has coronavirus (COVID-19), put the masks in a sealed plastic or paper bag and place in your rubbish bin. If other recyclable items such as paper and cardboard have mixed with the face masks, they should also be placed in the rubbish bin.

name: Masks (disposable)
advice:
Disposable face masks go in your rubbish bin.
Update: If you or someone in your household has coronavirus (COVID-19), put the masks in a sealed plastic or paper bag and place in your rubbish bin. If other recyclable items such as paper and cardboard have mixed with the face masks, they should also be placed in the rubbish bin.

name: Pillows
advice: Pillows go in your rubbish bin.

name: Shoes
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
You can take shoes to your nearest second-hand store, charity bin or drop-off location.
tips: in a good condition without any holes.
clean and not stained.

name: Coffee grounds
advice: But you can still recycle it…Some councils collect food waste for composting so coffee grounds can be recycled by putting them in the correct bin. To see if this happens in your local area check with your council. Or you can put them in a home compost, bokashi bin or worm farm. Some councils also offer discounted home compost bins and worm farms. Find out more about how to compost food waste.

name: Food scraps
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
Some councils collect food waste for composting so food scraps can be recycled by putting them in the correct bin. To see if this happens in your local area check with your council. 
Or you can put them in a home compost, bokashi bin or worm farm. Some councils also offer discounted home compost bins and worm farms. Find out more about how to compost food waste.

name: Medicines
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
Dispose of medicines for free at your local pharmacy through the Returned Unwanted Medicines Project.

name: Tea bags
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
Tea leaves can be composted but often the tea bag contains plastic or staples that can’t be composted. Check online to see if your tea brand uses compostable bags. 
Some councils collect food waste for composting so tea leaves can be recycled by putting them in the correct bin. To see if this happens in your local area check with your council. 
Or you can put them in a home compost, bokashi bin or worm farm. Some councils also offer discounted home compost bins and worm farms. Find out more about how to compost food waste.
tips: Remove any plastic labels or metal staples.
Check if your tea brand uses compostable bags.
If the bag isn’t compostable, open the bag to empty the leaves into the compost and then dispose of the bag in your rubbish bin.

name: Christmas trees (real)
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
Councils often have separate collections for real Christmas trees. For local services check with your local council.

name: Garden waste
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
If you have a garden waste bin, place your grass clippings, small branches, leaves and other garden waste in that bin.

name: Beer bottles
advice:
Unless…
Some councils may have other ways to collect glass bottles to prevent broken glass contaminating other recyclables. Check with your local council.
tips: empty any remaining beer.
don't include any broken glass. Find out how to dispose of broken glass.
collected by your local council’s kerbside recycling truck.
taken to a recycling sorting facility.
separated from other recyclables, such as plastic and cardboard.
taken to a glass treatment facility and washed, sorted by colour, then crushed and melted.
taken to a manufacturer to be made into new products.

name: Broken glass
advice: Broken glass goes in your rubbish bin inside a box or wrapped in newspaper.

name: Glass bottles
advice:
Unless...
Some councils may also have other ways to collect glass bottles to prevent broken glass contaminating other recyclables. Check with your local council.
tips: empty any remaining liquid or food.
don’t include any broken glass. Find out how to dispose of broken glass.
collected by your local council’s kerbside recycling truck.
taken to a recycling sorting facility.
separated from other recyclables, such as plastic and cardboard.
taken to a glass treatment facility and washed, sorted by colour, then crushed and melted.
taken to a manufacturer to be made into new products.

advice:
But you can still recycle it…

tips: in good condition.
not cracked or broken. Find out how to dispose of broken glass.

don't include any broken glass. Find out how to dispose of broken glass.
collected by your local council’s kerbside recycling truck.
taken to a recycling sorting facility.
separated from other recyclables, such as plastic and cardboard.
taken to a glass treatment facility and washed, sorted by colour, then crushed and melted.
taken to a manufacturer to be made into new products.

not cracked or broken.

not cracked or broken.

remove the plastic lid.
collected by your local council’s kerbside recycling truck.
taken to a recycling sorting facility.
separated from other recyclables, such as plastic and cardboard.
taken to a re-processing centre and broken down.
taken to a manufacturer to be made into new products.

taken to a recycling sorting facility.
separated from other recyclables, such as plastic and cardboard.
taken to a re-processing centre and broken down.
taken to a manufacturer to be made into new products.

name: Aluminium foil
tips: Make sure the aluminium foil is dry
Remove food scraps. Tear off any dirty or oily sections that can't be cleaned easily, and put them in your rubbish bin.
Loosely scrunch the clean and dry foil into a ball, at least the size of a golf ball. Recycling sorting machines can't process very small pieces of foil.
collected by your local council’s kerbside recycling truck.
taken to a recycling sorting facility.
separated from other recyclables, such as plastic and cardboard.
taken to a re-processing centre and broken down.
taken to a manufacturer to be made into new products.

tips: collected by your local council’s kerbside recycling truck.

separated from other recyclables, such as plastic and cardboard.

Unless…
the paper has a waxy or plastic coating. If the paper is coated – like deli wrappers, waxed paper and greaseproof paper – it needs to go in your rubbish bin.

Unless…
Books that are still in good condition can be taken to your nearest second-hand store, charity bin or drop-off location.

name: Disposable coffee cups
advice:
But you can still recycle them...
Some 7-Eleven will take your empty disposable coffee cups and lids. Find a disposable coffee cup recycling point near you. The cups and lids will be collected by Simply Cups, who will take them to a special facility that can process them for turning into new products.
If this isn't an option for you, put them in the bin.

name: Egg cartons
tips: collected by your local council’s kerbside recycling truck.
taken to a recycling sorting facility.
separated from other recyclables, such as plastic and steel.
taken to a re-processing centre and broken down.
taken to a manufacturer to be made into new products.

taken to a recycling sorting facility.
separated from other recyclables, such as plastic and steel.

taken to a manufacturer to be made into new products.

taken to a recycling sorting facility.
separated from other recyclables, such as plastic and steel.

name: Long-life cartons
advice:
Unless...
A few councils do accept long-life cartons in the recycling bin. Check with your local council.

taken to a recycling sorting facility.
separated from other recyclables, such as plastic and steel.
taken to a re-processing centre and broken down.

Unless…
Some councils don't allow milk cartons (cardboard only) in your recycling bin. Check with your local council.

taken to a recycling sorting facility.
separated from other recyclables, such as plastic and steel.
taken to a re-processing centre and broken down.
taken to a manufacturer to be made into new products.

name: Newspapers
tips: Remove protective plastic wrapping.
The newspaper should be dry.
collected by your local council’s kerbside recycling truck.
taken to a recycling sorting facility.
separated from other recyclables, such as plastic and steel.
taken to a re-processing centre and broken down.
taken to a manufacturer to be made into new products.

name: Paper (waxed)
advice: Put this in your rubbish bin.

name: Paper towel (used)
advice:
Put paper towel in your rubbish bin.
Update: If you or someone in your household has coronavirus (COVID-19), make sure the used paper towel is inside a plastic or paper bag that is securely closed before being placed in your kerbside rubbish bin. If other recyclable items such as paper and cardboard have mixed with the paper towel, they should also be placed in the rubbish bin.

name: Paper towel roll (inner)
tips: collected by your local council’s kerbside recycling truck.
taken to a recycling sorting facility.
separated from other recyclables, such as plastic and steel.
taken to a re-processing centre and broken down.
taken to a manufacturer to be made into new products.

tips: collected by your local council’s kerbside recycling truck.
taken to a recycling sorting facility.
separated from other recyclables, such as plastic and steel.
taken to a re-processing centre and broken down.
taken to a manufacturer to be made into new products.

name: Pizza boxes
tips: Remove any remaining pizza.
A little grease and baked on cheese is ok.
collected by your local council’s kerbside recycling truck.
taken to a recycling sorting facility.
separated from other recyclables, such as plastic and steel.
taken to a re-processing centre and broken down.
taken to a manufacturer to be made into new products.

name: Receipts
advice: Unless…they are made from thermal paper.Thermal paper is paper that fades over time or goes dark when near a heat source. Examples include some parking tickets, retail receipts and EFTPOS receipts. These need to go in your rubbish bin.

name: Tissues (used)
advice:
Put tissues in your rubbish bin. 
Update: If you or someone in your household has coronavirus (COVID-19), make sure the used tissues are inside a plastic or paper bag that is securely closed before being placed in your kerbside rubbish bin. If other recyclable items such as paper and cardboard have mixed with the tissues, they should also be placed in the rubbish bin.

name: Toilet paper (used)
advice: Any used toilet paper that is not flushed down the toilet should be put in your rubbish bin.

name: Wrapping paper
tips: collected by your local council’s kerbside recycling truck.
taken to a recycling sorting facility.
separated from other recyclables, such as plastic and steel.
taken to a re-processing centre and broken down.
taken to a manufacturer to be made into new products.

name: Crockery
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
You can take crockery to your nearest second-hand store, charity bin or drop-off location.
tips: in a good condition.
clean and not stained.

name: Cooking oils
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
Find a facility where you can dispose of cooking oil by contacting your local council.

name: Household chemicals
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
Household chemicals can be disposed of for free at a Detox your home event or contact your local council.

name: Paint
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
Household paint can be disposed of for free at a permanent drop-off site or contact your local council.

name: Corks
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
Check if there are any cork recycling programs near you by contacting your local council. If there are none, it goes in your rubbish bin.

name: Tyres (bicycle)
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
Check if there are any bike tyre recycling programs near you by contacting your local council. If there are none, it goes in your rubbish bin.

name: Tyres (car)
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
Check if there are any car tyre recycling programs near you by contacting your local council. If there are none, it goes in your rubbish bin.

name: Asbestos
advice:
What can I do with asbestos?
The Environmental Protection Authority Victoria (EPA) controls the disposal of asbestos in households.
Contact the EPA for more information about disposing of asbestos.

name: Building materials
advice:
But you can still recycle it...
Find a facility that will accept building materials such as a local recycling facility by contacting your local council.

name: Carpet
advice: But you can still recycle it...Find a facility that will accept carpet such as a local recycling facility by contacting your local council.

name: Fencing
advice:
But you can still recycle it...
Find a facility that will accept fencing such as a local recycling facility by contacting your local council.

name: Tools
advice:
But you can still recycle it...
Find a facility that will accept tools such as a local recycling facility by contacting your local council.

name: Window glass
advice:
But you can still recycle it...
Find a facility that will accept window glass such as a local recycling facility by contacting your local council.

name: Picture frames
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
You can take picture frames to your nearest second-hand store, charity bin or drop-off location.

name: Cookware (silicone)
advice: See if there are any local silicone recycling programs by contacting your local council. If there are none, it goes in your rubbish bin.

name: Cotton pads
advice: Used and unused cotton pads (as well as used make-up pads, cotton wool and cotton buds) go in your rubbish bin.

name: Cotton wool
advice: Used and unused cotton wool (as well as used cotton pads, make-up pads and cotton buds) go in your rubbish bin.

name: Dummies (silicone)
advice: See if there are any local silicone recycling programs by contacting your local council. If there are none, it goes in your rubbish bin.

name: Gloves (disposable)
advice:
Rubber, latex and silicone gloves go in your rubbish bin.
Update: If you or someone in your household has coronavirus (COVID-19), put the gloves in a sealed plastic or paper bag and place in your rubbish bin. If other recyclable items such as tissues, masks, paper and cardboard have mixed with the gloves, they should also be placed in the rubbish bin.

name: Menstrual cups (silicone)
advice: See if there are any local silicone recycling programs by contacting your local council. If there are none, it goes in your rubbish bin.

name: Pet droppings
advice: Put pet droppings in your rubbish bin.

name: Silicone
advice: See if there are any local silicone recycling programs by contacting your local council. If there are none, it goes in your rubbish bin.

name: VHS tapes
advice:
But you can still recycle it...
Some councils collect VHS tapes for recycling at special drop-off points. For information contact your local council.

name: Wet wipes (used)
advice: Put wet wipes in your rubbish bin. Update: If you or someone in your household has coronavirus (COVID-19), put the wet wipes in a sealed plastic or paper bag and place in your rubbish bin. If other recyclable items such as paper and cardboard have mixed with the wet wipes, you should place these in the rubbish bin also.

name: X-rays
advice:
But you can still recycle it…
See if there are any local x-ray recycling programs by contacting your local council. You can also find information about recycling x-rays by visiting Recycling Near You.
